instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LVDS_IG_BKL_ON: What is LVDS_IG_BKL_ON? LVDS_IG_BKL_ON is equivalent to LCD_BKLT_EN. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LVDS_DDC_CLK: What is LVDS_DDC_CLK? LVDS_DDC_CLK Is the DDC clock line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LVDS_DDC_DATA: What is LVDS_DDC_DATA? LVDS_DDC_DATA Is the DDC data line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
I messed up trying to scratch the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> in an attempt to find <SIGNAL>NC_LVDS_IG_BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> and damaged the <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> pin.

Is there another signal pin that i can use to just hardwire this? can I use <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
Which kind of damage?
<SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL>  is available at <RESISTOR>R2015</RESISTOR>, pin 1.

"to find <SIGNAL>NC_LVDS_IG_BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>"
All this damage because of not connected (NC) signal???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message: I was trying to do this but failed.[ATTACH type="full"]59772[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
Did you check them with LCD connected?
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> should also be high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message: Yes I did with LCD connected, it now chimes with only black screen, nothing shows even with flashlight shinning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LCD</SIGNAL>?
Check voltage and diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_CLK</SIGNAL>/DATA.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
There is no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LCD</SIGNAL> on this board?

diode mode to ground: <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_CLK</SIGNAL>/DATA = 370

i tried to connect <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>LCD_BLKT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>, I can see backlight but there is nothing on the screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
My mistake, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>...

Pin 4/J9000 gets 3V?

"Check [B][U]voltage[/U][/B] and diode mode"
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
If I left <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> connected to  <SIGNAL>LCD_BLKT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>:

- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
- Pin4/J9000 = <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_CLK</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
- <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_DATA</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

The screen was working until I scratch up and damaged <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>...

Should I remove <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and test again? but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> is derived from <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> which was 0v before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
Remove that jumper.
<CHIP>U9600</CHIP> may be damaged now!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message: Oh I forget to mention, <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> isnt presence on this board, it was removed and then hardwire bypass. The bypass was working before I scratched up the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
Then recover damaged trace ( <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> ).
The other signal is not needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
hmm... how? I think i have screwed up by over scratching the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>...

How come I dont see things on the screen if I jump 3.3v into  <SIGNAL>LCD_BLKT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> ?!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message:
So you've broken some traces near the PCH?

<SIGNAL>BKL_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA connects <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> with PCH.
Is not just an enable signal there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> alternatives
threads.message: i have broken some traces on the PCH itself... perhaps i have even killed the PCH but the machine chimes when power on..
